generated_text: The structure of ice II is a well-known example of a guest-enclathrated ice, in which the guest atoms are confined in a cage formed by the host molecules. In this work, we demonstrate that guest atoms can be enclathrated in the host molecules to form a new hydrate structure, which is different from the conventional ice-like hydrate structure. This work provides a new route to study the structure of guest-enclathrated ice and may have implications for the study of other hydrate structures.

The foundations of quantum mechanics are a major open problem in theoretical physics. The most promising approach to their solution is to develop a mathematical theory that is able to capture the essential features of quantum mechanics. In this paper, we develop such a theory, which we call “Hilbert space quantum mechanics.” The theory is based on a categorical approach to the foundations of mathematics. This approach is free of any analytical structure and is therefore applicable to any mathematical structure that can be represented by a category. We show that Hilbert space quantum mechanics is equivalent to a category of continuous linear operators on Hilbert spaces. This result provides a mathematical foundation for quantum mechanics that is free of any assumptions about the nature of space and time.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic parasites that cause diseases in both invertebrates and vertebrates. Although the evolutionary origin of myxozoans has been elusive, a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies and the observation that the distinctive myxozoan structure, the polar capsule, is remarkably similar to the stinging structures (nematocysts) in cnidarians. Here, we present the first genomic and transcriptomic analyses of two distantly related myxozoan species, Kudoa iwatai and Myxobolus cerebralis, and compare these to the transcriptome and genome of the less reduced cnidarian parasite, Polypodium hydriforme. Our results suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic parasitic cnidarian was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. These results have implications for understanding the origin of the Myxozoa and the evolution of parasitic lifestyles. (Less)

The ability of viruses to antagonize the antiviral action of interferons (IFNs) is a common defense strategy that they use to replicate and propagate in their host. In this study, we show that SARS-CoV-2 is able to efficiently block STAT1 and STAT2 nuclear translocation in order to impair transcriptional induction of IFN-stimulated genes (ISGs). Our results demonstrate that the viral accessory protein Orf6 localizes at the nuclear pore complex (NPC) and directly interacts with Nup98-Rae1 via its C-terminal domain to impair docking of cargo-receptor (karyopherin/importin) complex and disrupt nuclear import. In addition, we show that a methionine-to-arginine substitution at residue 58 impairs Orf6 binding to the Nup98-Rae1 complex and abolishes its IFN antagonistic function. All together our data unravel a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. This mechanism may be of particular importance in the context of the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. (Less)

The proton channel Hv1 is involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of Hv1. We use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the Hv1 dimer. We propose that Zn2+ binding has two major effects on Hv1: (i) at low concentrations, Zn2+ binds to one site and prevents the opening conformational change of the pore of Hv1, thereby inhibiting proton conduction; and (ii) at high concentrations, Zn2+, in addition, binds to a second site and inhibits the outward movement of the voltage sensor of Hv1. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 will further our understanding of Hv1 function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for Hv1 channels. The world’s population is expected to reach 10 billion by 2050, and the demand for food is expected to increase by 50% to meet this demand. The increase in demand will be even more pronounced in developing countries, where the population is expected to grow by 2.5 billion by 2050. This increase in demand will be accompanied by a warming of the climate, which will affect crop yields. We show that, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the coefficient of variation of maize yields will increase to values much larger than present-day values, and the probability that they have simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year will increase. These results highlight the urgency of investments in breeding for heat tolerance. (Less)

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is largely unknown because of the difficulty of identifying species-level diet. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant large mammals in semiarid African savanna. We found that the extent of diet overlap was greater between species that were similar in body size and proportional grass consumption than within either grass or browse guilds. These results suggest that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in large mammal assemblages, and that diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. Our results also highlight the importance of using DNA metabarcoding to identify species-level diet in future studies. This will be critical for understanding the role of large mammals in the functioning of ecosystems. (Less)

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a devastating impact on small businesses, which are the backbone of the US economy. We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses to understand the impact of the pandemic on their operations and finances. We find that many small businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Many businesses are financially fragile, and the majority plan to seek funding through the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act. However, many anticipate problems with accessing the program, such as bureaucratic hassles and difficulties establishing eligibility. Our results suggest that the CARES Act will be critical to supporting the survival of small businesses.

Plastic debris is one of the most visible consequences of the human impact on the environment. However, the magnitude of the problem is still unclear. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. This is due to the selective removal of the smaller particles by a combination of processes, such as nano-fragmentation, transference to the ocean interior, and ballasting. This study is of fundamental importance to understand the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean. It also provides a new perspective on the fate of the missing plastic debris. View Full-Text

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded rapidly. The effective catch per unit of effort has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries, challenging sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

The ability to increase the number of offspring produced in a given period of time is a defining characteristic of all species. This reproductive output is limited by the mother’s ability to care for and feed her offspring. Here, we show that the ability to provide additional resources to the mother correlates with an increase in reproductive output. We also show that the increase in reproductive output is due to an increase in the number of offspring produced rather than an increase in the size of each offspring. This suggests that the limiting factor on reproductive output is the mother’s metabolic power rather than resource availability. This is a fundamental insight into the evolution of reproduction in mammals and other species. (Less)

The accumulation of α-syn aggregates in oligodendrocytes is a pathological hallmark of multiple system atrophy (MSA). We show here that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765, which is well tolerated in humans, is able to limit the accumulation of α-syn aggregates in a mouse model of MSA. This effect was associated with a reduction of truncated α-syn, its monomeric and oligomeric forms. Finally, VX-765 was able to preserve tyrosine hydroxylase-positive neurons in the substantia nigra of PLP-SYN mice. These results suggest that VX-765 is a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in synucleinopathies by limiting α-syn accumulation. This would be of great importance for the treatment of this orphan neurodegenerative disorder. (PsycINFO Database Record

The endothelium is the lining of the blood vessels and is the interface between the blood and the tissues. It is the most numerous cell type in the body and is responsible for controlling the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between the blood and the tissues. The endothelium is also responsible for controlling the contractility of the blood vessels, hemostasis, and inflammation. The endothelium is a highly specialized cell type that is able to control its function by integrating information from multiple sources. The nature of the communication system that integrates the information has been poorly understood. Here, the nature of the communication system has been addressed using single-cell Ca2+ imaging across thousands of endothelial cells in intact blood vessels. The communication system is found to be a scale-free network with short path lengths. The scale-free network and short path lengths are found to be effective for efficient communication between the cells and rapid and robust communication between endothelial cells in order to efficiently control cardiovascular activity. These findings reveal the nature of the communication system that controls the function of the endothelium. The COVID-19 pandemic has been accompanied by a vast amount of data, much of which is publicly available. However, the data are often difficult to access and use. We describe the COVIDcast API, which provides open access to a rich set of data on the COVID-19 pandemic. The data are available through a simple web interface, and are also provided in a common format through an API. The data are useful for tracking the pandemic, and can be used to augment traditional public health reporting. The data are also useful for research and decision-making, and can be used to power new applications. The COVIDcast API is a resource that we hope will be useful to the public health community and beyond.

The selectivity filter and the activation gate in potassium channels are functionally and structurally coupled. This allosteric coupling underlies C-type inactivation coupled to activation gating in this ion-channel family. We have identified the second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for this allosteric communication. We show that this Threonine residue is essential for the structural coupling between the activation gate and the selectivity filter. We also show that the collapse of the selectivity filter can be used to achieve closed-state inactivation. This work provides a structural basis for the allosteric coupling between the activation gate and the selectivity filter in K+ channels. It also provides a structural basis for the use of the collapse of the selectivity filter to achieve closed-state inactivation. This work is of importance for the understanding of the function of K+ channels in health and disease. View Full-Text

The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is thought to play a critical role in the health of the host. The role of the gut microbiome in human health is still being elucidated, but it is clear that the composition of the microbiome is influenced by the host. The host can influence the microbiome by altering the diet, and the microbiome can influence the host by producing natural products that regulate the composition of the microbiome. This study shows that anaerobic fungi in the gut produce a variety of natural products that could be used to regulate the composition of the gut microbiome.

Social dominance is a key aspect of social behavior, and the study of social hierarchy is a major focus of research in the field of social psychology. However, the role of personality traits in social dominance is still unclear. Here we show that anxiety, a personality trait, directly influences social dominance in rats and identify an important mediating role for mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. Our findings highlight a key role for brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. This study provides a novel perspective on the role of personality traits in social behavior and may lead to the development of new therapeutic approaches. (PsycINFO Database Record

The design of mechanical structures with programmable and extreme responses is highly desired for various applications. However, the use of a single material phase and heuristically developed structural patterns leads to restricted design space and potential failure to achieve specific target behaviors. Here, we use a free-form inverse design approach to synthesize composite structures with multiple hyperelastic materials, which seamlessly collaborate to produce the target responses. The structures exhibit organic shapes and motions with irregular distributions of material phases. Within the structures, different materials play distinct roles yet seamlessly collaborate to produce the target behaviors. The synthesized structures are effectively manufactured via multimaterial fabrication with different polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS) elastomers with distinct behaviors and their highly nonlinear responses are physically and accurately realized in experiments. The proposed strategy can be utilized to design function-oriented and situation-specific mechanical devices for a wide range of applications. This work can also inspire the design of other complex structures with programmable and extreme responses.

The hemoglobin system is a key regulator of the timing of development and differentiation in the human body. The hemoglobin system is also a target of the let-7 miRNA pathway. Here we show that the let-7 pathway has a downstream element, IGF2BP1, that can affect the timing of hemoglobin expression in human erythroid tissues. We show that IGF2BP1 can be used as a chronoregulator of hemoglobin expression in human erythroid tissues.

Cancer is a leading cause of death worldwide, and the development of new therapies is urgently needed. In this study, we identified a mechanism of resistance to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent peroxidation of phospholipids, in cancer cells. This resistance is mediated by activation of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis, which, in turn, activates sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1), a central transcription factor regulating lipid metabolism. We also found that inhibition of SREBP1 or stearoyl-CoA desaturase-1 (SCD1), a transcriptional target of SREBP1, sensitizes cancer cells to ferroptosis induction. These results suggest that combination of mTORC1 inhibition with ferroptosis induction may be a promising strategy for the treatment of cancer. (Show more)

Hypertension is the most common cardiovascular disease, and the most important risk factor for heart failure. The major drugs for treating hypertension are L-type Ca2+ channel blockers (LCCBs), which are widely used in clinical practice. However, the molecular mechanisms of LCCBs action on Ca2+ signaling and vascular remodeling are not well understood. Here, we show that LCCBs activate STIM/ORAI-mediated Ca2+ entry in vascular smooth muscle cells, which is required for the development of vascular remodeling. Our findings provide a molecular basis for the use of LCCBs in the treatment of hypertension and heart failure.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the way forests were managed in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP halted the decline of older-forest–associated bird populations, but that the policy was insufficient to reverse the decline of these populations. Our findings underscore the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and ensuring that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure.

The development of new antibiotics is a major challenge for the medical community. The use of computational approaches is essential to this end since it enables fast and early strategical decisions in the drug development process. In this work, we present a rational design approach, in which acylide antibiotics were screened based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. The best candidate was tested in vitro and in vivo, and showed activity against antibiotic-resistant pathogens. The results of this work are expected to contribute to the development of new antibiotics. View Full-Text

Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems in recent works. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks is often very large, which makes it difficult to train the networks with large datasets. In this work, we introduce a network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters, and is easier to train and apply in practice. The proposed architecture is based on using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales and densely connecting all feature maps with each other. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters, and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters. We also show that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data.

The transport of moisture in the tropics is a critical process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. We present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa (9–15° S). The results show evidence for 24 lake level drops of more than 200 m during the Late Quaternary, including 15 lowstands when water levels were more than 400 m lower than modern. A dramatic shift is observed at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition (MPT), consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after 800,000 years ago. The results provide a unique insight into the evolution of the Lake Malawi endemic cichlid fish species flock, which is geographically extensive and has undergone rapid speciation in response to the extreme hydroclimate variability. The results have implications for the evolution of other species in the tropics. (Less)

The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime is widespread in the United States and around the world. This study shows that this practice has important consequences for sleep. When participants read an electronic book on a light-emitting device, they take longer to fall asleep, have reduced melatonin levels, and have later timing of their circadian clock. These results demonstrate that evening exposure to an electronic device phase-delays the circadian clock, acutely suppresses melatonin, and has important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety.

The Younger Dryas cooling is a well-known event in the Earth sciences, but the cause of the cooling is still debated. One of the most popular hypotheses is that one or more bolide impacts triggered the cooling. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YDB. We show that the Osmium isotope composition of the YDB magnetic grains is consistent with a terrestrial origin, and the YDB site in Pennsylvania is remarkable in yielding 2- to 5-mm diameter spherules containing minerals such as suessite that form at temperatures in excess of 2000 °C. The 187Os/188Os ratios of the spherules and their leachates are often low, but Os in these objects is likely terrestrially derived. The rare earth element patterns and Sr and Nd isotopes of the spherules indicate that their source lies in 1.5-Ga Quebecia terrain in the Grenville Province of northeastern North America. These results support the hypothesis that one or more bolide impacts triggered the YDB cooling. (Less)

The role of CTLA-4 in the regulation of immune responses has been extensively studied, but the impact of CTLA-4 deficiency in adult mice has not been fully explored. Here, we show that CTLA-4 deficiency in adult mice leads to spontaneous lymphoproliferation, hypergammaglobulinemia, and histologically evident pneumonitis, gastritis, insulitis, and sialadenitis, accompanied by organ-specific autoantibodies. However, this was not fatal. CTLA-4 deletion induced preferential expansion of CD4+Foxp3+ Treg cells. However, T cells from CTLA-4–deficient inducible KO mice were able to adoptively transfer the diseases into T cell-deficient mice. This indicates that CTLA-4 deficiency affects both central and peripheral tolerance and Treg cell-mediated suppression. Thus, our results provide a better understanding of the role of CTLA-4 in the regulation of immune responses and the development of autoimmunity. This may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of autoimmune diseases. (PsycINFO Database Record

The order Coleoptera is arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of beetles, including the impacts of plant feeding on beetle diversification, remain poorly understood. We used a combination of genomic and fossil data to trace the evolution of beetles and to estimate the timing and rates of beetle diversification. We also traced the evolution of genes enabling symbiont-independent digestion of lignocellulose, the major component of plant cell walls, and found that these genes were key to the Mesozoic diversification of herbivorous beetles. Our results suggest that the evolution of specialized plant-feeding habits, such as leaf mining and stem and wood boring, was enabled by the acquisition of microbial genes encoding enzymes that degrade plant cell walls. These results have important implications for our understanding of the evolution of beetles and the origin of insect herbivory. (Less)

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. (Less)

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of great interest to evolutionary psychologists. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We find that larger populations do not enhance CCE, and that it may be only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance CCE. Our results have implications for the evolution of human culture and the design of social systems. They also have implications for the design of large-scale experiments in the social and behavioral sciences.

The strongest genetic risk factor influencing late-onset Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is apolipoprotein E (APOE) genotype. APOE isoform is highly associated with AD risk, and APOE2 is protective, whereas APOE4 is associated with increased AD risk. APOE is also highly associated with the rate of astrocytic phagocytosis of senescent synapses, which may be a key event in AD pathogenesis. Here, we show that APOE isoform is highly associated with the rate of astrocytic phagocytosis of senescent synapses. We also show that APOE4 is associated with increased rate of C1q accumulation in hippocampus, which may be due to the increased rate of astrocytic phagocytosis of senescent synapses. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of astrocytic phagocytosis of senescent synapses. They also suggest the hypothesis that APOE4 may be associated with increased AD risk in part due to defective astrocytic phagocytic capacity, which accelerates the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses and enhances their vulnerability to complement-mediated neurodegeneration. The Earth's inner core is a solid sphere with a diameter of 2,890 km, which is the largest and densest solid body in the solar system. The formation of the inner core is one of the most important and controversial issues in geophysics. The two main hypotheses are the melting and the crystallization. However, the crystallization is difficult to explain because of the high degree of undercooling required for nucleation. In this study, we demonstrate that the nucleation of the inner core is likely to be the two-step process, in which the bcc phase is the first stable phase to nucleate, and then the hcp phase nucleates from the bcc phase. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox. The two-step nucleation scenario of the inner core also opens an avenue for understanding the structure and anisotropy of the present inner core. (Less)

The use of marijuana is widespread, and its abuse is increasing. The effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain are not well understood. Here, we show that the brain’s reactivity to methylphenidate (a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine [DA]) is reduced in marijuana abusers, who also have higher levels of negative emotionality and addiction severity. These findings suggest that the brain’s reactivity to DA stimulation might contribute to the negative emotionality and addictive behaviors of marijuana abusers.

Language is a uniquely human cognitive skill, and the brain’s mechanisms for comprehending it are among the most complex and mysterious aspects of the human brain. Here, we use a large-scale, integrative modeling approach to show that the most powerful artificial neural network models for predicting brain activity during language processing also predict brain activity across many models, many datasets, and many imaging modalities. These results provide computational evidence for the predictive-processing theory of language comprehension and suggest that the brain’s language machinery is tuned to the most important computations for understanding language. The approach presented here could have broad implications for understanding the brain’s processing of other complex natural signals.

Deep learning (DL) has had unprecedented success in many scientific applications. However, the stability of DL methods is still an open problem. We show that there are problems in scientific computing where one can prove the existence of stable neural networks (NNs), but there does not exist any algorithm, even randomized, that can train (or compute) such a NN. This is a fundamental paradox, which we address by introducing a classification theory of stability. We prove that only a small number of layers are needed for an ϵ-accurate solution to the inverse problem. Moreover, we prove that only O(|log (ϵ)|) layers are needed for an ϵ-accurate solution to the inverse problem. This is a fundamental paradox, which we address by introducing a classification theory of stability. The COVID-19 pandemic has been described as a “perfect storm” of factors, including the failure of governments to act quickly enough, the failure of the health care system, and the failure of people to follow the rules. One of the most prominent arguments is that people are unable to understand exponential growth. This argument is based on a classic psychological experiment published 45 years ago. We discuss the critical design flaws of this experiment, which have been overlooked for decades. We also discuss the implications of this case study for the study of human behavior and the design of experiments.

Leprosy is a neglected disease that affects the poorest people in the world. The causative agent, Mycobacterium leprae, has undergone extensive reductive evolution, and the genome sequence of the only cultured strain, M. leprae, is now available. We sequenced the genome of a second human pathogen, M. lepromatosis, which is associated with a different clinical phenotype, and compared the two genomes. We found that the two pathogens have retained the ability to infect the peripheral nervous system, and that they have retained the ability to cause disease in humans. These findings suggest that despite their ancient separation, the two leprosy bacilli are remarkably conserved and still cause similar pathologic conditions. This is important for the development of new drugs and vaccines. (PsycINFO Database Record

The emergence of thermodynamics from quantum mechanics is one of the most fundamental and puzzling questions in physics. The entanglement dynamics is a key ingredient in this process, as it is responsible for the accumulation of entropy. However, the entanglement dynamics is a highly nonlocal phenomenon, which makes it difficult to analyze. Here, we show that the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit can be completely understood in terms of quasiparticles, which are the elementary excitations of the system. We check our result for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain, and we find perfect agreement with the exact solution. Our work opens the way to the study of the entanglement dynamics in interacting systems, which is a long-standing challenge. It also paves the way to the study of the entanglement dynamics in interacting systems in the space–time scaling limit.

The COVID-19 pandemic has claimed the lives of more than 3.5 million people worldwide. The only available vaccines are based on inactivated virus or viral vector technology, which are not suitable for mass vaccination. Here, we describe the development of a live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine, which is currently in clinical development. The vaccine is based on the recoding of the viral spike protein, which is the target of the neutralizing antibodies. The recoded spike protein is temperature sensitive, which allows for the production of a live vaccine at room temperature. The vaccine is highly protective in hamsters and can be used for mass vaccination programs. This is a major step forward in the fight against the COVID-19 pandemic. (Show more)

The Second Pandemic of plague (14–19th centuries) led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. The vector of the disease is still debated, with the most common hypothesis being that rats were the main transmission pathway. Here, we show that human ectoparasites, such as fleas or lice, were the main transmission pathway during the Black Death (1347–1353). This contradicts the assumption that the Black Death was caused by rats and supports the hypothesis that the Black Death was a human disease. Our results have important implications for the history of plague and the development of control measures. They also have implications for the spread of the disease in the Middle Ages and the early modern period. View Full-Text

The evolution of brain size has been a major focus of research in the field of comparative neurobiology. However, the evolution of brain information-processing capacity has been less explored. This study shows that the evolution of brain size is not the only factor that determines the evolution of brain information-processing capacity. We show that the evolution of brain information-processing capacity is also affected by the evolution of the number of neurons. This study also shows that the evolution of brain information-processing capacity is not only driven by the evolution of brain size but also by the evolution of the number of neurons. These results have important implications for the study of the evolution of brain information-processing capacity and animal cognition.

The role of TRAP1 in cancer is controversial. Some studies suggest that TRAP1 is a tumor suppressor, whereas others suggest that it is an oncoprotein. We have used TRAP1-null cells and transient TRAP1 silencing/overexpression to show that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1-deficient cells also display strikingly enhanced invasiveness. TRAP1 may act as a tumor suppressor in some settings. These data suggest that TRAP1 may be a promising target for cancer therapy. (PsycINFO Database Record

Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF) is a key regulator of the actin cytoskeleton. It is involved in a variety of cellular processes, including cell migration, cell division, and cell differentiation. However, the mechanism by which ADF regulates actin dynamics is not fully understood. Here, we show that ADF can induce a mechanical torque on actin filaments, which enhances severing. This mechanochemical mechanism is critical for ADF to sever highly connected filament networks in cells. Our results provide a mechanism for how ADF can regulate the mechanical properties of the actin cytoskeleton. They also provide a general mechanism for how mechanical forces can enhance the activity of proteins that bind to filaments. These results have implications for understanding the role of ADF in cells and other systems. View Full-Text

Fructose, a sweetener found in many foods and beverages, is widely used in the United States and is the most common sweetener in soft drinks. The present study shows that fructose ingestion relative to glucose results in greater activation of brain regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings have implications for understanding the role of fructose in the development of obesity and diabetes. (PsycINFO Database Record

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, and we found that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. The distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the admixture was sex biased and happened heterogeneously across Madagascar, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia rather than settlement by an already admixed population. In addition, we found that a few centuries is sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. These results help to understand the history of Madagascar and the origin of the Malagasy people. They also provide a framework for the development of genomic tools to study the history of other island populations. View Full-Text

We show that people’s emotions can be influenced by the emotions of others in a large social network. This is a major finding, because it suggests that people are influenced by the emotions of others without their awareness. It also suggests that in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people. These results have implications for the design of social networks, and for the way that people use social networks. They also have implications for the study of emotions in social networks.

The presence of chemical modifications in messenger RNAs (mRNAs) is a common feature of the transcriptome. The most prevalent modification in coding regions is pseudouridine (Ψ), which is found in 10–20% of mRNA molecules. We show that the presence of Ψ in the mRNA sequence can have a modest effect on translation. Our work suggests that the presence of Ψ in coding regions can modestly alter both translation speed and mRNA decoding. This is an important finding, as the presence of Ψ in coding regions is common and the number of Ψ-containing mRNAs is increasing. Our results have implications for the interpretation of experiments that use Ψ-modified mRNAs and for the design of experiments that use Ψ-modified mRNAs. (Show more)

The feeling that one’s life is worthwhile is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that this feeling is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes in older age, including better health, stronger social relationships, and a healthier lifestyle. These associations are robust to the inclusion of a range of potential confounders and mediators, and they are not driven by factors such as depressive symptoms or prosperity. The feeling that life is worthwhile may promote healthy aging and help sustain meaningful social relationships and optimal use of time at older ages. These findings have implications for public health and policy. (PsycINFO Database Record

The evolution of larger body size is a defining characteristic of the evolution of life on land. This study shows that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving the evolution of larger body size in four of the five extant aquatic mammal lineages. The existence of this body size attractor and the relatively rapid selection toward, and limited deviation from, this attractor rule out most hypothesized drivers of size increase. These three independent body size increases and a shared aquatic optimum size are consistent with control by differences in the scaling of energetic intake and cost functions with body size between the terrestrial and aquatic realms. Rather than being released from size pressures, water-dwelling mammals are driven and confined to larger body sizes by the strict energetic demands of the aquatic medium.

The common cold is the most common viral infection in the world, and rhinoviruses are the most common cause of the common cold. The temperature dependence of rhinovirus replication has been attributed to a failure of the host antiviral response at cool temperatures. Here, we show that the host antiviral response is more efficient at warm temperatures, and that this accounts for the preferential replication of rhinoviruses at nasal cavity temperature. Our findings have implications for the development of antiviral strategies for the common cold. (Show more)

The ability to sense and respond to environmental signals is a key feature of life. In this study, we show that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its pili to sense the presence of surfaces. This mechanosensory system is part of a complex regulatory network that controls the expression of virulence factors and biofilm formation. Our findings have implications for the development of new strategies to combat this pathogen.

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically in recent decades, and the use of newer-generation insecticides has increased even more. However, the impact of these changes on the quality of surface water is unknown. We show that the use of newer-generation insecticides has increased the risk of exceeding the legally accepted regulatory threshold levels for surface water and sediments. This is the first time to our knowledge that such a comprehensive analysis has been conducted. Our results highlight the need for worldwide improvements to current pesticide regulations and agricultural pesticide application practices and for intensified research efforts on the presence and effects of pesticides under real-world conditions.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a devastating impact on human health and the global economy. The virus has also spread to many animal species, including deer, and may persist in the wild animal population. Here, we describe the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in white-tailed deer, which are the predominant cervid in North America. We also show that the virus is circulating in deer during the winter, when human cases are declining. These findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic and the need for a proactive “One Health” approach to study the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. (Less)

The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a major concern for the environment, people, and climate change. This paper examines the causes of the proliferation of large dams in the developing world, the problems associated with them, and the solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices. We also propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is a neurodegenerative disorder that is characterized by the presence of extracellular plaques and intracellular neurofibrillary tangles. The exact cause of AD is unknown, but it is believed to be the result of a complex interplay between genetic and environmental factors. In this study, we demonstrate that soluble and oligomeric forms of amyloid-β (Aβ) are the primary drivers of an early immune response in the brain, which may lead to the development of AD. Our results suggest that the accumulation of Aβ in neurons may be a significant factor in the pathogenesis of AD.

The domestication of chickens (Gallus gallus domesticus) is one of the most important events in the history of agriculture. The earliest evidence for the domestication of chickens comes from the archaeological site of Catalhoyuk, Turkey, where the remains of a wild chicken were found in association with the remains of a human hunter-gatherer. However, the earliest evidence for the economic exploitation of chickens is still missing. Here we present the results of a faunal analysis of 234 sites in the Southern Levant, spanning more than three millennia. Our results show that the earliest secure evidence for economic exploitation of chickens in Europe dates to the first century B.C.E. and therefore is predated by the finds in the Southern Levant by at least a century. We suggest that the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, the latter fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period, was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later.

The folding of proteins is a key process in biology, and it is of great interest to understand the details of the folding pathways. The study of the folding of proteins is complicated by the fact that the folding process is a dynamic process, and the structure of the folding intermediates is not known. Here we study the folding of the maltose binding protein, a large protein that folds in two distinct steps. We use a combination of methods to determine the structure of the folding intermediates. The results provide insight into the folding process of this and other proteins. (Show more)

The accumulation of dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress has been shown to be a key mechanism for regulating gene expression in bacteria. However, the cellular response to stress is often accompanied by the formation of disulfide bonds, which can inactivate enzymes involved in the formation of Np4-capped RNAs. Here, we show that, in the presence of disulfide stress, the RNA pyrophosphohydrolase RppH, which is normally responsible for decapping Np4-capped RNAs, becomes the predominant enzyme responsible for the deprotection of those transcripts. This finding has important implications for the regulation of gene expression during stress. (Show more)

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality and poor clinical outcomes. The development of severe sepsis is associated with a sustained immune dysfunction, which is characterized by lymphopenia, increased apoptosis, and the emergence of myeloid-derived suppressor cells (MDSCs). We hypothesized that increasing arginine availability would restore T cell function and decrease immunosuppression during sepsis. We found that citrulline, a nonessential amino acid, was more efficient than arginine in increasing arginine plasma levels and restoring T cell mitochondrial function and proliferation while reducing immunosuppression. Because there is no specific therapeutic strategy to restore immune function after sepsis, we believe that our study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. This study also provides evidence for the use of citrulline as a potential therapeutic strategy in cancer. View Full-Text

The biomass of the biosphere is a key quantity for understanding the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined. Our analysis reveals that the global marine biomass pyramid contains more consumers than producers, thus increasing the scope of previous observations on inverse food pyramids. Finally, we highlight that the mass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined and report the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a global view of the biomass of the biosphere and can be used to better understand the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. View Full-Text

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a fascinating phenomenon in nature and in physics, where a system evolves in time toward a critical state, in which the system’s evolution is self-sustaining. The critical state is characterized by a power-law distribution of the system’s activity, which is the measure of the system’s activity. The power-law distribution is the hallmark of SOC. In this paper, we report on our discovery of a tropical model with self-organized criticality (SOC) behavior. Our model is continuous, in contrast to all known models of SOC, and is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We describe how our model is related to pattern formation and proportional growth phenomena and discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is used in many applications, including sensors, lasers, and electronics. However, diamond is brittle and has a low fracture toughness, which limits its applications. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly under mechanical strain, and that the metallization can be used to control the bandgap of diamond. This work provides opportunities for tailoring the properties of diamond for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. It also provides a new route to control the phase of diamond, which is important for applications in energy storage and catalysis. This work is expected to have a significant impact on the development of diamond-based technologies.

The study of the structure and function of peptides is of great interest to the scientific community. The study of the antifungal activity of peptides is of even greater interest to the scientific community. However, there is a lack of knowledge regarding the structural architecture, antifungal activity, and modes of action of antifungal peptides. Here, we report the solution structure of a unique antifungal peptide, the 36-amino acid NCR044, and its antifungal activity against multiple plant fungal pathogens. We also report the mode of action of this peptide against plant fungal pathogens. Our work illustrates the antifungal activity of a structurally unique NCR peptide against plant fungal pathogens and paves the way for future development of this class of peptides as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide. This work will be of interest to the scientific community and will help to advance the field of peptide research.

The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction between the sexes. In this study, we provide a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome. We show that the proteome of Drosophila sperm undergoes substantial changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. We also show that the female reproductive tract provides a source of proteins that support sperm viability during the prolonged period between copulation and fertilization. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. (Show more)

The common human bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease, is caused by mutations in the ultralong protein von Willebrand factor (VWF). The mutations alter the structure of the protein, which in turn alters its function. We show that the structure of the protein can be switched by force, providing a mechanism for the function of the protein to be switched in vivo. The force-switchable structure is a key element in the mechanism of action of VWF on platelets.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of microorganisms that has been shown to influence human health and disease. However, the human virome, the set of viruses that live in or on humans, has been difficult to study because of the lack of a comprehensive database. This study provides a database of human-associated viruses, which can be used to study the human virome and its impact on human health. The database includes information on the location of the virus in the human body, the host species, and the disease or condition associated with the virus. The database can be used to identify potential targets for antiviral therapies and to understand the role of viruses in human disease. The database can also be used to study the diversity and dynamics of the human virome over time.

The aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) process is one of the most important processes in the climate system. However, the ACI process is very complex and difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the lack of observational capability. The dual-FOV high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL) is a new instrument that can provide high-resolution and simultaneous observations of aerosols and water cloud properties. This instrument is expected to be a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. The observations obtained from the dual-FOV HSRL constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI process. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. This is expected to lead to a better understanding of the role of ACI in climate change. This will be of great importance to the global climate.

The temperature of Earth’s surface has been a topic of interest for many years. The temperature of the surface of the Earth is important because it is the surface temperature that determines the temperature of the atmosphere, and the temperature of the atmosphere is important because it determines the chemistry of the atmosphere, and the chemistry of the atmosphere is important because it determines the chemistry of the biosphere, and so on. The temperature of the surface of the Earth is also important because it is the temperature of the surface of the Earth. This paper presents a method for determining the temperature of the surface of the Earth in the past. The method is based on the thermostability of ancestral enzymes. The results of this study are important because they provide a new method for determining the temperature of the surface of the Earth in the past. The results of this study are also important because they provide a new perspective on the coevolution of life and environment over Earth history. (Less)

Ion channels are the main regulators of ion flow in the body. They are also the main targets of drug development. The K+ channel KCNB1 is the gene responsible for the cardiac disease hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. The K+ channel BK is the main drug target for the treatment of hypertension. The K+ channel BK is also the main drug target for the treatment of asthma. The K+ channel BK is the main drug target for the treatment of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. The K+ channel BK is the main drug target for the treatment of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. The K+ channel BK is the main drug target for the treatment of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.

The malaria parasite must overcome a number of barriers to enter the human red blood cell (RBC). The invasion process is complex, involving a number of parasite proteins and host cell receptors. Here, we show that the malaria parasite uses a single protein, erythrocyte-binding antigen 175 (EBA175), to bind to a single host cell receptor, glycophorin A (GPA), and that this interaction alters the biophysical properties of the RBC. We show that the reduction in the bending modulus of the RBC membrane is correlated with parasite invasion efficiency. This finding suggests that the malaria parasite primes the RBC surface through its binding antigens, altering the biophysical nature of the target cell and thus reducing a critical energy barrier to invasion. This is a major change in our concept of malaria parasite invasion, suggesting it is, in fact, a balance between parasite and host cell physical forces working together to facilitate entry. (Less)

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is used in many applications, including sensors, lasers, and electronics. However, diamond is brittle and has a low fracture toughness, which limits its applications. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly under mechanical strain, and that the metallization can be used to control the bandgap of diamond. This work provides a new approach to tailoring the properties of diamond, which can be used in many applications.

The impact of ambient humidity on the severity of influenza virus infection is a topic of great interest. In this study, we show that housing mice in low humidity increases the susceptibility of mice to influenza virus infection. We also show that low humidity impairs host defense against influenza infection and reduces tissue repair. These results suggest that low humidity may be a risk factor for influenza virus infection in the temperate regions. Our findings may help to elucidate the impact of ambient humidity on the severity of influenza virus infection and may provide insights into the development of strategies to mitigate the impact of influenza virus infection in the temperate regions. (Show more)

The brain is thought to build syntactic structures in a bottom-up, phrase-by-phrase manner. Here, we show that the brain’s activity increases with each successive word in a sentence but decreases suddenly whenever words can be merged into a phrase. This merge operation is applied equally to linguistic objects of arbitrary complexity, providing evidence for a merge mechanism that applies to the brain’s representation of sentences and word lists. Our results suggest that the brain uses a phrase-by-phrase merge operation to build syntactic structures. This is the first time that such a mechanism has been observed in the brain. It is also the first time that the brain’s activity has been linked to the construction of a linguistic object of arbitrary complexity. Our findings have implications for theories of language processing and for the design of artificial systems for language understanding. View Full-Text

The canonical Wnt pathway is a major signaling pathway in vertebrates that is involved in development and homeostasis. The pathway is regulated by the degradation of β-catenin, which is inhibited by the binding of the Axin proteins to β-catenin. We show here that the two forms of Axin in vertebrates are similar at the protein level and genetically redundant. We show that differential regulation of the two genes on the transcriptional and proteostatic level confers differential responsiveness that can be used in tissue-specific regulation. Such subtle features may distinguish other redundant gene pairs that are commonly found in vertebrates through gene knockout experiments. This work provides a deeper understanding of the regulation of redundant genes and their importance in the development of vertebrates. It also provides a resource for future studies on the regulation of redundant genes. This work is of interest to the general public and the scientific community.

The brain circuit that promotes overeating is not well understood. Here we describe a circuit that is activated by electrical or optogenetic stimulation of the lateral hypothalamus. This circuit is composed of a group of GABAergic neurons that project to the ventral tegmental area and inhibit dopamine neurons there. We also show that this circuit is critical for the rapid eating that occurs after stimulation of the lateral hypothalamus. This circuit may contribute to the development of obesity.

The ability of bacteria to fix atmospheric nitrogen is a key process in the evolution of life and is of great interest for the future of agriculture. However, the use of free-living nitrogen-fixing bacteria in agriculture is currently limited by the lack of a sustainable way to control the establishment of the beneficial symbiosis. Here, we demonstrate the development of a synthetic plant-controlled nitrogen-fixing symbiosis, in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This work is expected to have a significant impact on the future of agriculture. (Less)

The Amazon is the world’s most important tropical forest, and its deforestation is a major cause of climate change. Despite substantial investments in remote-sensed forest monitoring, early deforestation alerts rarely reach the most directly affected populations in time to deter deforestation. We study a community monitoring program that facilitated transfer of early deforestation alerts from the Global Forest Watch network to indigenous communities in the Peruvian Amazon and trained and incentivized community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. Our results suggest that the program reduced deforestation, but the estimated effects from the experiment are imprecise. Should our findings be replicated elsewhere, they imply that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

The sense of hearing is a fundamental ability of many animals, including all mammals, birds, some reptiles, amphibians, fish, and arthropods. The auditory organs of these animals are extremely diverse in anatomy after hundreds of millions of years of evolution, yet they are all made up of cellular tissue and are morphologically part of the body. Here, we show that hearing in the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius is not constrained by the organism’s body but is extended through outsourcing hearing to its extended phenotype, the proteinaceous, self-manufactured orb web. We find that the spider’s web acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna to sense the motion of web threads, which is better than the acoustic responsivity of all previously known eardrums. By outsourcing its acoustic sensors to its web, the spider is released from body size constraints and permits the araneid spider to increase its sound-sensitive surface area enormously, up to 10,000 times greater than the spider itself. The outsourcing and supersizing of auditory function in spiders provides unique features for studying extended and regenerative sensing and designing novel acoustic flow detectors for precise fluid dynamic measurement and manipulation. The health and climate impacts of anthropogenic aerosols and greenhouse gases are difficult to disentangle. We use a global model to estimate the climate and health benefits of a phaseout of fossil fuel use, and the additional benefits of controlling other anthropogenic sources. We find that a phaseout of fossil fuels can save 3.61 million lives per year, and that additional reductions of nonfossil anthropogenic sources can save 5.55 million lives per year. The model also shows that aerosols mask the anthropogenic warming, and that removing anthropogenic particles can reduce the warming by 0.51 °C globally. We conclude that a rapid phaseout of fossil fuels and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C. Our results highlight the importance of the climate and health impacts of anthropogenic aerosols and greenhouse gases. (Less)

The COVID-19 pandemic has claimed over 2 million lives worldwide. The global distribution of COVID-19 cases and deaths is not only a public health concern but also a major economic burden. The development of vaccines is the most effective way to control the pandemic. The development of vaccines is a complex process that requires a large number of resources. In this study, we report the development of a recombinant protein subunit vaccine that can be manufactured at a large scale and can be used to control the pandemic. The vaccine can be used to control the pandemic in both high- and low-income countries. The vaccine can be used to control the pandemic in both high- and low-income countries.

The development of neural crest-derived tissues is a complex process involving multiple signaling pathways. In this study, we show that the zebrafish homolog of the anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK) gene, drALK, is required for the development of iridophores, a pigment-producing tissue of the skin. We also show that the zebrafish homolog of the leukocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk) gene, drLtk, is required for the development of iridophores. Our results suggest that the ALK/Ltk signaling pathway is involved in the regulation of neural crest development. This pathway may be relevant to the development of neuroblastoma, a cancer of neural crest origin. Our results also provide evidence for the existence of a ligand–receptor system in the nervous system. This system may be relevant to the development of other tissues. (Show more)

The emergence of plague as a devastating pathogen is a topic of great interest to the scientific community. However, the early history of plague is poorly understood due to the lack of ancient DNA evidence. Here, we present 17 Yersinia pestis genomes from the Eurasian Late Neolithic/Early Bronze Age (LNBA) period, which spans 5,000 to 2,500 y ago. Our results show that the LNBA Y. pestis lineage was nonflea-adapted and potentially extinct, and that the flea-adapted form of plague emerged in the Bronze Age in Iberia. These data provide insights into the early evolution and ecology of plague, and the spread of this disease across Eurasia. They also highlight the importance of ancient DNA in the study of ancient pathogens. (Less)

This work examined the role of the culturally endorsed form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—in predicting support for Donald Trump in the 2016 American presidential election and Joe Biden in the 2020 American presidential election. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, HM predicted support for Trump in the days (Studies 1 and 2) and months (Studies 3 through 6) following the 2016 election. HM was also associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia. These findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. (PsycInfo Database Record

The management of agricultural lands has a profound impact on the global carbon cycle. In the United States, the conversion of grasslands to cropland has led to the release of 1.5 Pg of carbon to the atmosphere. This study shows that the management of agricultural lands can be used to sequester carbon in the soil. The results of this study have implications for the management of agricultural lands worldwide. The management of agricultural lands can be used to sequester carbon in the soil. The results of this study have implications for the management of agricultural lands worldwide. (Less)

The death toll and economic loss resulting from the severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) pandemic are stark reminders that we are vulnerable to zoonotic viral threats. We developed a risk assessment framework to identify and prioritize wildlife viruses with the greatest potential to spillover and spread in humans. We validated the framework using data from a virus discovery project and public records of virus detections around the world. The resulting ranking of 887 wildlife viruses can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. This work is a step toward a more comprehensive understanding of the risk of spillover and spread of viruses in the future. (Less)

Nectar is a reward that plants offer to animals for pollination. The color of nectar is an important cue for animals searching for food. In this study, we show that the red color of the nectar of Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We also show that the red color of the nectar of N. mauritianus is attractive to the gecko pollinators of this species. This work provides evidence for the convergence of this trait in two species of plants visited by hummingbirds. This suggests that the red color of nectar is a simple and effective way for plants to attract pollinators.

The history of Europe is marked by complex demographic processes, including the arrival of new populations and the spread of new genetic variants. However, the genetic history of the period between the migrations and the invasions is largely unknown. Here we present a genome-wide analysis of a group of women from Bavaria, Germany, who had been deformed by cranial cranial deformation. The analysis of their collective genetic ancestry suggests that they had a genetic background that was very different from that of the rest of the population. In addition, we show that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. These findings contribute to our understanding of the genetic history of Europe and provide insights into the processes that shaped the modern European genetic landscape. (Less)

The receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5 were investigated. The results suggest that the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of bat coronaviruses are dependent on the host species. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmission. These findings are important for understanding the origin of MERS-CoV and the evolution of bat coronaviruses. They also provide insights into the pathogenesis of MERS-CoV in humans. (PsycINFO Database Record

The ability to rapidly identify the cause of undifferentiated febrile illness is critical to the early detection and control of epidemics. We used a global cloud-based metagenomic sequencing platform to identify the pathogens responsible for undifferentiated febrile illness in a periurban population in Cambodia. We found that vector-borne pathogens were the most common cause of undifferentiated febrile illness, but that underappreciated zoonotic pathogens, such as Plasmodium knowlesi, leptospirosis, and coinfecting HIV, were also common. Our findings underscore the importance of ongoing pathogen surveillance in resource-scarce settings, where epidemics are likely to emerge, and demonstrate the feasibility of pathogen surveillance using a global cloud-based metagenomic sequencing platform. This approach can help identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens and deployment of rapid public health response. (PsycInfo Database Record

The lagging strand of the double helix is synthesized by DNA polymerase δ (pol δ) in the presence of the sliding clamp proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA). The stability of this complex is integral to every aspect of lagging strand replication. In this study, we developed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. We found that the human pol δ holoenzyme maintains a loose association with PCNA while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. This study provides a unique perspective on the structure and function of the pol δ holoenzyme and its role in DNA replication. It also provides a unique insight into the structure and function of the PCNA sliding clamp. (Show more)

The origin of life is one of the most important problems in biology. In the hypothesized RNA world, before the evolution of proteins, genetic information was stored in RNA molecules. In this study, we used in vitro evolution to improve the activity of an RNA polymerase ribozyme, which can synthesize RNA from an RNA template. The improved polymerase ribozyme can synthesize a variety of complex structured RNAs, including aptamers, ribozymes, and, in low yield, even tRNA. Furthermore, the polymerase can replicate nucleic acids, amplifying short RNA templates by more than 10,000-fold in an RNA-catalyzed form of the PCR. Thus, the two prerequisites of Darwinian life—the replication of genetic information and its conversion into functional molecules—can now be accomplished with RNA in the complete absence of proteins. This work represents a significant step toward the reconstruction of RNA-based life. (PsycINFO Database Record

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearance of five US cities with economic and demographic data and find three factors that predict neighborhood improvement. First, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements—an observation that is compatible with the economic literature linking human capital and local success. Second, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements—an observation that is consistent with “tipping” theories of urban change. Third, neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods—an observation that is consistent with the “invasion” theories of urban sociology. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also suggest that the physical appearance of neighborhoods may be a key factor in the success of urban policy.

The clinical characteristics of severe and critical COVID-19 patients are analyzed, and the immune characteristics of these patients are summarized. The results show that the immune system of these patients is in a state of imbalance, and the immune response is not strong enough to fight the virus. Tocilizumab, which targets the IL-6 pathways, can effectively reduce the mortality of severe and critical COVID-19 patients.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but also a toxic metal that can cause damage to cells and tissues. The existence of natural products that bind and sequester copper in fungi is surprising, as fungi are generally considered to be nonmetallurgists. The existence of the xan biosynthetic gene cluster in several filamentous fungi suggests a heretofore unknown role of eukaryotic natural products in copper homeostasis and mediation of interactions with competing microbes. These findings have implications for the understanding of the role of natural products in the evolution of fungi and their interactions with other organisms. (Show more)

The formation of tridymite in a sedimentary environment is unusual, but it has been documented in terrestrial mudstones. The presence of tridymite in a sedimentary deposit at Gale crater, Mars, is significant because it provides evidence for the presence of high-temperature (≥870 °C) fluids in the past. The presence of tridymite in a sedimentary deposit at Gale crater, Mars, is significant because it provides evidence for the presence of high-temperature (≥870 °C) fluids in the past.

Frost is a major abiotic stress that affects the performance of plants and animals across the world’s temperate and boreal zones. Despite their ecological and economic impact, the geographic distribution and evolutionary impact of these frost events are poorly understood. We show that the geographic distribution of frost risk is changing in the Northern Hemisphere, and that the resistance strategies of trees are not adapted to the new frost regimes. Our findings can help decision-makers in land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy to adapt to the ongoing changes in frost frequencies. Our results also provide a framework for understanding the impact of other climate-related changes, such as drought, on the performance of plants and animals.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory response in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, it is not known whether the Th17 phenotype is maintained in the cells that contribute to disease. Here, we show that the Th17 phenotype is maintained in a subset of Th17 cells, but not in Th17 cells that contribute to disease. We also show that Th17 cells can provide “help” for the development of classic Th1 cells. These results have implications for the development of therapeutic strategies for inflammatory bowel disease.
