Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by degeneration of motor neurons, leading to paralysis and death. The disease is caused by mutations in genes encoding motor neuron proteins, but also by genetic risk factors, such as the C9orf72 hexamer expansion. We now report a method to rapidly produce motor neuron-like cells from living patients with ALS, which can be used to study disease mechanisms and to screen for drugs that alleviate toxicity to motor neurons. This will help to identify new therapeutic targets and lead to the development of new treatments for ALS. (Show more)

The ability of pathogens to influence the composition of the host microbiota is a key factor in pathogen colonization and disease. Here, we show that the human pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum induces ticks to express antifreeze glycoprotein (iafgp), which alters the composition of the gut microbiota and facilitates the colonization of the tick. IAFGP binds the terminal d-alanine residue of the pentapeptide chain of bacterial peptidoglycan, resulting in altered permeability and the capacity of bacteria to form biofilms. These findings elucidate the molecular mechanisms by which a human pathogen appropriates an arthropod antibacterial protein to alter the gut microbiota and more effectively colonize the vector. This work provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of the tick microbiota in pathogen colonization and may lead to the development of new strategies to control vector-borne diseases. (Show more)

The evolution of the avian tail is one of the most important transitions in the history of birds. The study of the early evolution of the avian tail is therefore critical for understanding the origin of the modern avian body plan. Here, we describe a new basal member of the short-tailed bird group, Jinguofortis, from the Early Cretaceous of China. This new taxon adds important information about the early evolution of the short-tailed bird group and increases our understanding of the origin of the modern avian body plan.

The climate system is a complex system, and it is difficult to understand the behavior of the climate system without a detailed understanding of the underlying processes. In this paper, we show that the water vapor in the stratosphere plays an important role in the climate system. This is significant because the water vapor in the stratosphere is not directly measured, and it is difficult to measure.

The evolution of color in animals is one of the most striking features of the natural world. The presence of blue-green colors in the natural world is a consequence of the presence of the pigment biliverdin, which is the reduced form of the protein bilirubin. In this study, we show that the presence of high concentrations of biliverdin in anurans (frogs and toads) has evolved multiple times during their evolutionary history, and that this phenomenon is linked to the presence of a group of serpins that bind biliverdin. Our results provide a molecular and functional explanation for the evolution of chlorosis, and introduce a function for a member of the serpin superfamily, the largest and most ubiquitous group of protease inhibitors. This study also provides a molecular explanation for the presence of blue-green colors in the natural world. (Less)

Hypoxia is a key feature of many solid tumors, and is associated with increased proliferation and metastasis. However, the mechanisms by which hypoxia promotes tumor growth are not fully understood. Here we show that hypoxia induces expression of ALKBH5, an m6A demethylase, which in turn increases the expression of NANOG, a gene encoding a pluripotency factor. NANOG expression is regulated by hypoxia and HIF-1α, and is dependent on ALKBH5. NANOG overexpression mimics the effect of hypoxia on breast cancer cells, and ALKBH5 knockdown reduces the number of breast cancer stem cells. Thus, ALKBH5 is a key mediator of the effects of hypoxia on breast cancer stem cells. Our findings have implications for the development of therapeutic strategies for breast cancer. The use of fetal animal skins for parchment has been a long-standing controversy in codicology. The term “uterine vellum” is often used to describe this type of parchment, but the source of this material has been unclear. Here, we report the results of a study that uses a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. The method is based on the use of a PVC eraser to generate an electrostatic charge on the parchment surface, which is then analyzed by mass spectrometry. The results show that the source of this parchment was not fetal animals, but rather the skins of maturing animals of several species. This suggests that the production process allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness. The results also suggest that the use of fetal animals for parchment was not a widespread practice in the Middle Ages. (Less)

The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the development of vaccines and therapeutics. The D614G mutation is the most prevalent in circulating virus, and it is hypothesized to increase infectivity. We use cryo-electron microscopy to compare the structure of the D614G and G614 spikes and show that the G614 mutant spike is more open and may facilitate binding to the receptor. These results provide insight into the mechanism of the D614G mutation and may help guide the development of future vaccines and therapeutics. (Show more)

We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States, and Black and Latino Americans have experienced a disproportionate burden of COVID-19 morbidity and mortality. We estimate life expectancy at birth and at age 65 y for 2020, for the total US population and by race and ethnicity, using four scenarios of deaths—one in which the COVID-19 pandemic had not occurred and three including COVID-19 mortality projections produced by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation. Our medium estimate indicates a reduction in US life expectancy at birth of 1.13 y to 77.48 y, lower than any year since 2003. We also project a 0.87-y reduction in life expectancy at age 65 y. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006. Our findings underscore the importance of addressing the structural inequalities that increase risk of exposure to COVID-19 and mortality risk for those infected. (Psy

The chemical properties of atoms are of fundamental importance in chemistry and are also key to understanding the origin of the chemical diversity of the elements. In this work, we show that the chemical properties of atoms, such as electronegativity and chemical hardness, decrease with pressure, and we discover that the elements preceding Ni, Pd, and Pt become pseudo–noble-gas atoms with a closed d-shell configuration, and the elements right after them become highly electropositive. We show the explicative and predictive power of our electronegativity and chemical hardness scales. Our results are of fundamental importance in chemistry and are also key to understanding the origin of the chemical diversity of the elements. They are of direct relevance to the study of the chemical properties of matter under extreme conditions, such as in the interiors of stars and in the laboratory. They are also of direct relevance to the study of the chemical properties of matter in the future exoplanets that will be discovered by the next generation of space telescopes.

Climate change is expected to increase global temperatures, but the effects of fire on climate are poorly understood. We show that changes in fire activity, driven by climate, demography, and human activity, can have a significant impact on the global carbon cycle. Our results suggest that changes in fire activity can offset ∼5 to 10 y of global CO2 emissions at today’s levels. This could be important in reducing the rate of global warming. However, our results also show that the effects of fire on climate are highly uncertain, and the risk of more extreme fires is also high. Our study highlights the importance of fire in the global carbon cycle and the need to better understand the effects of climate change on fire regimes. This will be critical in predicting the future of the global carbon cycle and climate.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microorganisms is a common strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their mutualistic associations. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are poorly understood. Here, we show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, is sufficient to maintain the health of the symbiotic bacterium Vibrio fischeri in the squid Euprymna scolopes. We also show that the glycan is provided and metabolized only at night, and that the glycan is required for the periodic acidification of the symbiotic organ that is necessary for the health of the symbionts. These results suggest that the provision of nutrients may be a general mechanism used by animals to maintain the health of their symbionts. This is an important finding, as it suggests that the provision of nutrients may be a common mechanism used by animals to maintain the health of their symbionts.

The study of topics in text data is a central problem in natural language processing. We introduce a method to identify topics in a corpus and represent documents as topic sequences. Our method is based on advances in theoretical machine learning and can be applied to any domain. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. Our results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. This work is a step toward the goal of understanding the world around us through the language we use.

The second plague pandemic, which started with the arrival of Yersinia pestis in Europe in the 14th century, lasted for four centuries. This period is generally understood as the consequence of a single introduction of the bacterium, after which it established itself in European rodents. Our study shows that the introduction of Y. pestis into Europe was preceded by climate-driven reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. This suggests that the bacterium was not introduced into Europe as a result of a single event, but rather that it was introduced repeatedly. Our results have important implications for the understanding of the spread of the plague in Europe. (Less)

The sea star wasting disease (SSWD) is one of the most devastating diseases affecting marine organisms in recent years. The disease has been observed in at least 12 species of sea stars, affecting populations in the North and South Pacific, the Mediterranean Sea, and the Atlantic Ocean. The disease is caused by a virus, but the identity of the virus and the mechanism of spread are unknown. Here, we show that the virus is present in the tissues of diseased sea stars and that the disease is associated with an increase in the virus load. The virus is also present in the environment, suggesting that the disease is spread by the movement of infected sea stars. These findings provide a better understanding of the disease and may lead to the development of control measures.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia, and the prognosis of AML is poor. There is an urgent need for novel and more efficient therapies for AML, ideally targeting AML stem cells that are essential for maintaining the disease. We show here that monoclonal antibodies targeting the IL1RAP (IL1R3) receptor on AML cells have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects and that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. We also show that an antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling can suppress the proliferation of primary human AML cells. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. Furthermore, the results suggest that the antibody can be used to treat other diseases that are associated with IL-1 signaling. This is an important step toward the development of a new class of drugs for the treatment of AML. (PsycINFO Database Record

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar, and we found that the island was colonized by different groups from Africa and Asia, with a sex-biased and heterogeneous admixture. The results suggest that the settlement of Madagascar happened in several independent waves, and that the island was colonized by an already admixed population. In addition, we found that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a new perspective on the settlement history of Madagascar, and it is a step toward understanding the origin of the Malagasy people. This work is also important for the understanding of the origin of the human populations in the Indian Ocean. (Less)

Bacteria have evolved small RNAs (sRNAs) to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The 164-nucleotide RNA was previously shown to encode a 28-amino acid protein (denoted AzuC). We discovered the membrane-associated AzuC protein interacts with GlpD, the aerobic glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase, and increases dehydrogenase activity. Overexpression of the RNA encoding AzuC results in a growth defect in glycerol and galactose medium. The defect in galactose medium was still observed for a stop codon mutant derivative, suggesting a second role for the RNA. Consistent with this observation, we found that cadA and galE are repressed by base pairing with the RNA and base pairing interferes with AzuC translation. These results demonstrate that the translation and base-pairing functions compete. This is an example of a dual-function RNA that has evolved to control carbon utilization.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. (Less)

Crop experts are the primary source of information on the status of crops in the field. However, their assessments are subjective and qualitative, and are not easily amenable to quantitative analysis. We show how to convert the original qualitative data into a continuous, probabilistic variable better suited to quantitative analysis. We also show how to use this index to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. Our results demonstrate the potential of using crop expert assessments to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. This has important implications for the management of agricultural production and the early detection of crop anomalies. Our approach can be easily extended to other crops and countries.

Language is a complex cognitive ability that is thought to involve the ability to integrate and store information in working memory. Here we propose a mechanism for memory that is based on the adaptive changes in the excitability of single neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind linguistic features over time. We show that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind linguistic features over time. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language. It also has implications for the study of memory in general.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, and its response to climate change is of critical importance for predicting future changes in the carbon cycle. However, despite considerable scientific attention in recent decades, the overall response of soil respiration to anticipated climatic warming remains unclear. We synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming. The transition from autotrophy to a nonphotosynthetic parasitic lifestyle is one of the most important events in the evolution of plastids. It is also one of the most poorly understood. We present a model of the trajectory of plastid genome evolution during the transition from autotrophy to a parasitic lifestyle. We show that the transition is associated with a gradual relaxation of functional constraints on plastid genes, which is linked to the establishment of a parasitic lifestyle. Our findings suggest that the transition to obligate parasitism relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner. This process is likely to have contributed to the diversification of plastid gene complexes and their functional complexity. The model presented here can be used to predict the evolutionary trajectories of plastid genomes under different environmental conditions. This can be used to predict the evolutionary trajectories of plastid genomes under different environmental conditions. (Less)

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark example of the impact of climate change on water resources in South Africa and other regions of the world. We show that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (SSP5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. (Less)

The discovery of quasicrystals in the aftermath of the first nuclear test, the Trinity test, has been a major event in the history of science. The discovery of the oldest known anthropogenic quasicrystal in the red trinitite, the first sample of which was collected 70 y ago, is a major event in the history of science and technology. The discovery of this quasicrystal, which was formed in the aftermath of a nuclear explosion, is a reminder of the importance of nuclear testing in the advancement of science and technology.

The biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophyll pigments is among the most productive biological pathways on Earth. Photosynthesis relies on these modified tetrapyrroles for the capture of solar radiation and its conversion to chemical energy. The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring, the key reaction in the biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophylls, has remained a mystery for more than 60 y. This reaction is catalyzed by two unrelated cyclase enzymes using different chemistries. The majority of anoxygenic phototrophic bacteria use BchE, an O2-sensitive [4Fe-4S] cluster protein, whereas plants, cyanobacteria, and some phototrophic bacteria possess an O2-dependent enzyme, the major catalytic component of which is a diiron protein, AcsF. Plant and cyanobacterial mutants in ycf54 display impaired function of the O2-dependent enzyme, accumulating the reaction substrate. Swapping cyclases between cyanobacteria and purple phototrophic bacteria reveals three classes of the O2-dependent enzyme. These data delineate three classes of O2-dependent cyclase in chlorophototrophic organisms from higher plants to bacteria, and their evolution is discussed herein. (Show

Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature in neurodegenerative diseases, such as multiple sclerosis (MS). Neuroinflammation is also a major feature in experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE), a model of MS. Neuroinflammation is associated with the activation of mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase kinase (MAP3K) ASK1, which is known to be involved in neuroinflammation. However, the precise cellular and molecular mechanisms of ASK1 in neuroinflammation remain unknown. In this study, we found that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages plays a major role in neuroinflammation, and ASK1 in astrocytes exacerbates neuroinflammation in a MAP3K-dependent manner. Our findings suggest that ASK1 in astrocytes may be a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. These findings may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for neurodegenerative diseases. (PsycInfo Database Record

The 2012–2014 drought in California is the driest on record and has led to acute water shortages, groundwater overdraft, critically low streamflow, and enhanced wildfire risk. We find that the probability of drought has increased in the past two decades, and that the probability of drought has increased if precipitation deficits occur when conditions are warm. We also find that anthropogenic forcings have increased the probability that dry precipitation years are also warm. Thus, anthropogenic warming is increasing the probability of co-occurring warm–dry conditions like those that have created the acute human and ecosystem impacts associated with the 2012–2014 drought in California. This finding has important implications for climate change adaptation in California and other regions of the world. (Less)

Autism is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder with a high heritability and a complicated etiology. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, specifically, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. This study provides a framework for identifying the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms. It also provides a potential target for the development of behavioral therapies for autism. This work is the most comprehensive cross-national demonstration of negativity biases to date. It also highlights individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content. The results help account for the tendency for audience-seeking news around the world to be predominantly negative. They also suggest that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of cellular Ca2+ homeostasis, and mutations in the pore-forming protein ORAI1 or the Ca2+ sensor STIM1 lead to severe immune dysfunction and myopathy. Here, we identify gain-of-function mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1, which lead to spontaneous bleeding and thrombocytopenia in patients with Stormorken syndrome. These data expand our understanding of the phenotypic spectrum of dysregulated CRAC channel signaling, advance our knowledge of the molecular function of the CRAC channel, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. The study of spreading of protein aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases is of great interest because it may help to identify the mechanisms that lead to the progressive loss of neurons. Here we show that the spread of aggregates in the Drosophila brain is dependent on the presence of a defined set of neurons, which we call the “aggregator neurons.” These neurons are responsible for the accumulation and subsequent spreading of aggregates throughout the brain. We also show that the spread of aggregates is dependent on the release of aggregates from the “aggregator neurons” and their uptake by other neurons. These results provide a model for the study of spreading of aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

The study of the immune system in bats is of great importance for understanding the evolution of the immune system and the origin of the adaptive immune system in mammals. The one-carbon unit is essential for cell growth, and is provided by the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT). SHMT is up-regulated in cancer, and the enzyme is a promising target for cancer therapy. Here we report the discovery of a series of small-molecule dual inhibitors of SHMT1 and SHMT2. We show that these compounds are effective in vitro and in vivo, and that they are particularly effective in B-cell lines. We also show that formate, the one-carbon donor, is a potent rescue of SHMT inhibition, but paradoxically increases the inhibitor’s cytotoxicity in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. These results suggest that SHMT inhibition is a promising therapeutic strategy for B-cell malignancies. Thus, we have identified a promising target for cancer therapy. (Less)

The presence of proteins that are supersaturated in the brain and spinal cord of patients with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) suggests that these proteins are prone to aggregation. However, the presence of these proteins in the brain and spinal cord of patients with ALS is not explained by the presence of the same proteins in the brain and spinal cord of other human tissues. We show that the presence of these proteins in the brain and spinal cord of patients with ALS is explained by the presence of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, but not in other human tissues. These results suggest that the presence of proteins in inclusion bodies in ALS is explained by the presence of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons. This metastable state is likely to be the result of a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in motor neurons. This is a significant finding, as it suggests that the presence of inclusion bodies in ALS is not simply a reflection of the presence of the same proteins in other human tissues. It also suggests that the presence of inclusion bodies in ALS is a marker of disease progression.

The study of quantum many-body systems is a central theme in modern physics. The development of new experimental tools is essential for the advancement of this field. In this work, we present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium (Cs) atoms. The photonic crystal is designed to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. The photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. This work is expected to have broad impact on the field of quantum many-body physics. (Show more)

The origin of the flowering plants is a major topic in the history of life. The early diversification of the flowering plants is poorly understood, and the role of aquatic habitats in this diversification is still controversial. The study of Montsechia, a fossil plant from the Cretaceous, has allowed us to understand the early evolution of the flowering plants.

The evolution of viruses is a key topic in the field of virology, but it is difficult to study because of the short time scales involved. We have used ancient human remains to study the evolution of human parvovirus B19 (B19V), which is associated with a number of conditions, such as fifth disease in children and arthritis and arthralgias in adults. We find that B19V has been associated with humans for a long time, and we are able to date the recombination event that formed the most common B19V genotype. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. (Less)

Sea level is a sensitive indicator of climate change. In this study, we provide a new estimate of the rate of sea level rise over the last 25 y, which is used to project sea level rise over the next 30 y. We find that the rate of sea level rise is accelerating, and that the rate of sea level rise in 2010 was the highest in the satellite altimeter era.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that, for those with less education, each successive birth cohort has a higher prevalence of pain at each age—a result not found for those with a bachelor’s degree. The increase seen across birth cohorts cannot be explained by changes in occupation or levels of obesity for the less educated, but fits a more general pattern seen in the ongoing erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950. If these patterns continue, pain prevalence will continue to increase for all adults; importantly, tomorrow’s elderly will be sicker than today’s elderly, with potentially serious implications for healthcare.

The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of structural biology. The application of NMR-assisted crystallography to the study of the tryptophan synthase α-aminoacrylate intermediate provides a chemically detailed, three-dimensional picture of structure and reactivity that is key to understanding the reaction pathway back to the preceding transition state. This study highlights the power of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide mechanistic insight into the dynamics of enzyme active sites.

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe respiratory disease caused by a coronavirus that emerged in 2012. There is no specific antiviral treatment for MERS, and the high mortality rate of the disease stresses the need for the availability of effective antiviral treatments. Here, we show that remdesivir, a nucleotide analog, is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in a nonhuman primate model. The data presented here support testing of remdesivir treatment in the context of a MERS clinical trial, and it may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This may be of particular importance in the current context of the COVID-19 pandemic.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microorganisms is a common strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their mutualistic associations. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are poorly understood. Here, we show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, is sufficient to maintain the health of a symbiotic bacterium, Vibrio fischeri, in the squid Euprymna scolopes. We also show that the glycan is provided and metabolized only at night, when the squid is producing light. This is the first example of a nutrient being provisioned and metabolized only at specific times of the day, and it suggests that the timing of nutrient provision may be a general strategy used by animals to control the activities of their symbionts.

DNA alkylation is one of the most common DNA lesions, which can lead to transcriptional mutagenesis. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated how RNA polymerase II (pol II) recognizes and bypasses regioisomeric O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (O2-, N3-, and O4-EtdT) lesions. We found that the transcriptional lesion bypass routes for the three EtdT lesions are controlled by distinct fidelity checkpoints. The error-free transcriptional lesion bypass route is strongly favored for the minor-groove O2-EtdT lesion. In contrast, a dominant error-prone route stemming from GMP misincorporation was observed for the major-groove O4-EtdT lesion. Finally, we identified a minor-groove–sensing motif from pol II (termed Pro-Gate loop). The Pro-Gate loop faces toward the minor groove of RNA:DNA hybrid and is involved in modulating the translocation of minor-groove alkylated DNA template after nucleotide incorporation opposite the lesion. Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes severe respiratory disease. To better understand the mechanisms of MERS-CoV infection, we engineered viruses with mutations that blocked sequential proteolysis of the virus spike (S) glycoproteins. These mutations compromised MERS-CoV infection into human lung-derived cells, but had little effect on infection into several other cell types. These cell type-specific requirements for proteolysis correlated with S conformations during cell entry. Without the first cleavages, S proteins resisted cell receptor-induced conformational changes, which restricted the second, fusion-activating cleavages. Our findings suggest that sequential proteolysis is a determinant of MERS-CoV virulence.

The food system is a major contributor to global warming and other environmental problems, and to population health problems such as obesity. One promising approach to reducing these problems is to increase the proportion of plant-based meals in catering outlets. However, the impact of such changes on sales of meat meals has not been systematically examined. We show that doubling the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a large catering outlet increased vegetarian meal sales by 40% and decreased meat meal sales by 15% in the same outlet. These results provide robust evidence to support the potential for simple changes to catering practices to make an important contribution to achieving more sustainable diets at the population level. Our results also suggest that it may be possible to achieve these changes without a significant impact on overall sales. This is an important step toward achieving the goal of increasing the proportion of plant-based meals in catering outlets to a level that is sufficient to have a significant impact on population health and the environment.

The cell surface is the interface between the cell and its environment, and is a major target for cancer therapy. Here we use a combination of mass spectrometry and activated ion electron transfer dissociation to study the surfaceome of a breast epithelial cell line stably expressing oncogenes, and show how the surfaceome is remodeled in a cell autologous fashion. We find that the surfaceome is a major target for oncogenes, and that the functions of the surfaceome are harmonized by common biological themes. We also show how the surfaceome is remodeled in response to a potent MEK inhibitor, and suggest possible surface targets and combinations thereof for drug and biomarker discovery. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets and combinations thereof for drug and biomarker discovery. (PsycINFO Database Record

The 2020 presidential election is likely to be the first in which voters will be able to cast their ballots by mail. As a result, many scholars and policy makers are urging the United States to expand vote-by-mail programs to safeguard the electoral process. What are the effects of vote-by-mail? In this paper, we provide a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effect of universal vote-by-mail—a policy under which every voter is mailed a ballot in advance of the election—on electoral outcomes. We find that universal vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media.

The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the molecular basis of viral pathogenesis. In this study, we describe the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which is unique in its ability to form large-scale assemblies. These assemblies may be important for immune suppression and evasion. The structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8 provides a foundation for the development of new antiviral strategies. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a common environmental stressor that can induce cerebral edema. However, the underlying mechanisms are not well understood. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and that this is mediated by the release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus, which acts on the cortex via its receptor CRFR1 to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA in cortical astrocytes, leading to activation of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and cerebral edema. This study provides a better understanding of the mechanisms of cerebral edema and may lead to the development of new therapies. (Show more)

The problem of selective inference is of great importance in the era of big data. We describe some recent developments in this area and illustrate their use in forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis. The key idea is that the data that we have mined for associations are not random, and so we must set a higher bar for declaring significant the associations that we find. This is a fundamental challenge in the analysis of big data.

The development of endothelial cells (ECs) is a complex process that requires the coordinated action of multiple transcription factors. In this study, we identified ets variant 2 (ETV2) as a transcription factor that induces the development of ECs from nonvascular cells. ETV2 is a member of the ETS family of transcription factors, which are known to be important for the development of hematopoietic cells. However, the role of ETV2 in EC development has not been reported. Our results indicate that ETV2 is a key factor for the development of ECs and that ETV2-induced ECs exhibit characteristics of mature ECs. Furthermore, ETV2-induced ECs can be used for the regeneration of blood vessels in vivo. These findings provide a new approach for the generation of ECs and the regeneration of blood vessels. (Show more)

The discovery of the ligand for the orphan receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk) has led to the identification of a third ligand, augmentor, which is also an Alk/Ltk ligand. We show that the augmentor ligands play an important role in zebrafish pigment development. We also show that the augmentor ligands are essential for the development of iridophores, a specialized type of tissue that is found in the skin of many vertebrates. These experiments establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. This work provides a foundation for understanding the physiological role of Alk/Ltk ligands and their importance in the development of iridophores. This work also provides a foundation for understanding the role of Alk/Ltk ligands in cancer.

The role of STING in the regulation of insulin sensitivity has been well established. However, its function in β-cells remains unknown. Herein, we found that STING is decreased in islets of db/db mice and patients with type 2 diabetes, suggesting a possible role of STING in β-cell dysfunction. Indeed, STING deficiency caused glucose intolerance due to impaired insulin secretion, indicating that STING is required for normal β-cell function. These data revealed a function of STING in the regulation of insulin secretion and established pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. These findings may provide a new perspective for the development of therapeutic strategies for type 2 diabetes. (Show more)

The influenza A virus is a single-stranded RNA virus that infects birds and humans. It is responsible for an annual influenza epidemic and occasional severe pandemic. The genome of the influenza A virus is segmented into eight fragments, which complicates the packaging of the genome into the viral particles. We identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral RNA segments of an avian influenza A virus. This interaction is required for optimal viral replication and favors the copackaging of the interacting viral RNA segments. Our results indicate that viral RNA segments can promote the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome by forming a sequence-dependent supramolecular network of interactions. This interaction might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. (Show more)

The development of atherosclerosis is a complex process involving a series of events, including the activation of proatherosclerotic phenotypes of vascular endothelial cells. The present study demonstrates that the activation of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) by disturbed flow is a critical event in the development of atheroprone phenotypes and atherosclerotic lesion formation. Our results provide a mechanistic understanding of the functional role of YAP/TAZ in the development of atherosclerotic lesions and suggest that inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising therapeutic strategy for the prevention of atherosclerosis. Therefore, this study provides a potential target for the development of athero-protective drugs. (Show more)

Wildfires are a natural part of the ecosystem, but they can also be a threat to human life and property. The economic and ecological costs of wildfire in the United States have risen substantially in recent decades. Although climate change has likely enabled a portion of the increase in wildfire activity, the direct role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We show that humans have vastly expanded the spatial and seasonal “fire niche” in the United States, accounting for 84% of all wildfires and 44% of total area burned. Our results highlight the importance of human-caused wildfires and the need for increased management of these fires.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearance of five US cities with economic and demographic data and find three factors that predict neighborhood improvement. First, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements—an observation that is compatible with the economic literature linking human capital and local success. Second, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements—an observation that is consistent with “tipping” theories of urban change. Third, neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods—an observation that is consistent with the “invasion” theories of urban sociology. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also suggest that the physical appearance of neighborhoods may be a key factor in the success of urban policy.

Natural repellents are a class of plant-derived compounds that are used to protect humans and animals from insect bites. However, the molecular targets of natural repellents in arthropods are still unknown. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study sheds light on arthropod molecular targets of natural repellents, exemplifying the arthropod–plant adaptation. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. View Full-Text

The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with severe fetal abnormalities and neurological complications. The mechanisms of disease are not fully understood, but the role of the virus in the host has been studied in nonhuman primates. Here we present a mathematical model of ZIKV dynamics in a nonhuman primate model, allowing for characterization of the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques. We show that the model can be used to predict the effect of antiviral treatment on the time to undetectable plasma viral load. We also show that the model can be used to predict the effect of the timing of treatment on the time to undetectable plasma viral load. These predictions can be used to guide the design of clinical trials. (Less)

Coral bleaching is a well-known phenomenon that is triggered by heat stress and causes the death of the coral host. However, the underlying causes of bleaching are still poorly understood. Here, we show that the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is driven by altered nutrient cycling during heat stress. Our results provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. This work also has important implications for the management of coral reefs, as it highlights the importance of nutrient cycling in the early stages of bleaching. (Less)

The intestinal epithelium is the main barrier between the host and the environment. It is also the main site of nutrient absorption and immune surveillance. In the present study, we show that the loss of BMP signaling in the intestinal epithelium leads to the development of intestinal tumors, which in turn trigger a regenerative response in the microbiome. This leads to a loss of the intestinal barrier, which in turn promotes tumor growth. Our work highlights the importance of controlling the activity of JNK signaling to maintain the integrity of the intestinal epithelium and host–microbe homeostasis. It also provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of the microbiome in tumorigenesis. These findings have implications for the development of therapeutic strategies to control tumor growth. (Less)

The development of therapies that can improve the response to chemotherapy in breast cancer is an important goal. Here we show that targeting the type I tyrosine kinase-like orphan receptor ROR1 can enhance the response to chemotherapy in mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts. This effect was associated with the inhibition of the activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, and BMI1, which are important in the regulation of breast cancer stemness. These results suggest that targeting ROR1 may be a promising strategy for improving the response to chemotherapy in breast cancer. (Show more)

The timing of the start of accelerated deglaciation in the Southern Hemisphere is a key issue in the debate about the role of stratospheric ozone depletion in the past. We show that the start of deglaciation is linked to a volcanic eruption, which led to stratospheric ozone depletion and a climate response that was similar to that observed today. This finding has important implications for the interpretation of past climate changes and the role of stratospheric ozone depletion in the past. (Less)

Freshwater fisheries are a critical source of food, recreation, and commerce for hundreds of millions of people around the world. However, they are often overlooked in global assessments of fisheries and biodiversity. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of the world’s catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. Our analysis also shows that freshwater fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people, particularly in regions where rivers are most threatened by other stressors. Our data can be used to identify the most productive and vulnerable rivers, and to prioritize the development of sustainable fisheries and the protection of biodiversity. This information is critical for the conservation of freshwater ecosystems and the provision of essential ecosystem services. (Less)

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. However, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The unique nanosized and metastable character of the negative electrode material is the key to achieve high-energy aqueous batteries. This work combines a high capacity with a safe negative electrode material through delivering the Mo-based oxide with unique nanosized and metastable characters. This work provides a new strategy for the development of inherently safe energy devices. This work is expected to be a milestone in the field of aqueous batteries. View Full-Text

The ability to regenerate after injury is a defining feature of the adult nervous system. In the past decade, we have made significant progress in understanding the molecular mechanisms that control the ability of neurons to regenerate. However, the mechanisms that control the intrinsic regenerative capacity of the adult nervous system are still largely unknown. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is independent of the canonical MAPK signaling pathway, which is known to mediate regeneration in the adult nervous system. This discovery provides a powerful platform for the discovery of genes that control the intrinsic regenerative capacity of the adult nervous system. Moreover, our study suggests that the intrinsic regenerative capacity of the adult nervous system is a conserved feature of the nervous system, as it is found in the adult C. elegans and mammalian CNS.

The process of DNA recombination is fundamental to the functioning of the genome. In this study, we describe the distribution of recombination across the genome of a flowering plant, Mimulus guttatus. We find that recombination is concentrated in hotspots, interspersed with cold regions. The distribution of hotspots is similar to that observed in yeast and in mice, suggesting that the process of recombination in plants may be conserved from yeast to humans.

The resting state of the brain is a complex and poorly understood phenomenon. Here, we used metabolic positron emission tomography to identify and validate reproducible RSN topographies in healthy and disease populations. We found that the dominant RSN was topographically similar to the default mode network, whereas the subordinate RSNs were associated with Parkinson’s disease. In addition, we found that the dominant RSN was deactivated during task performance, whereas the subordinate RSNs were activated. These results provide a direct and objective method for the study of the resting organization of the brain in health and disease. They also provide a basis for the development of new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of neuropsychiatric disorders.

The 5′ cap structure is the most important modification of mRNA. It is essential for the stability and translation of mRNA. The existence of 5′ cap-like structures on nuclear and mitochondrial transcripts has been suggested, but their existence has not been proven. We show that 5′ NAD-RNA is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial transcripts in yeast. This 5′ NAD+ cap is produced cotranscriptionally and is not modified after transcription. The 5′ NAD+ cap may have a role in the regulation of gene expression.

The study of epigenetic mechanisms has led to the discovery of DNA-methylation alterations in diabetes that are associated with the development of complications. We show that these DNA-methylation alterations persist over time and are associated with glycemia in the long-term follow-up of people with diabetes. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory, the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive vs. conventional therapy on the progression of microvascular complications in the long-term follow-up of the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT). This study also provides a possible mechanism for the beneficial effects of intensive therapy on the progression of complications in diabetes. These findings may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of diabetes.

The role of the fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) in the progression and drug sensitivity of triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. (PsycInfo Database Record

Alcohol dependence is a chronic and relapsing disease, which is characterized by a high mortality rate. The present study shows that the gut barrier is altered in alcohol-dependent subjects, which may be related to the development of psychological disorders. Moreover, the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in these subjects, suggesting that the gut microbiota is involved in the development of the disease. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence. This study also provides a possible explanation for the high mortality rate of this disease. (PsycINFO Database Record

The production of volatile compounds is a key feature of many plant species, and the biosynthesis of these compounds is of interest for both fundamental and applied reasons. The biosynthesis of volatile nitrogenous compounds in tomato fruit is poorly understood, and the identification of the enzymes involved in this process will be of interest to the flavor industry. Here, we report the identification of a gene essential for the production of all the nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. This gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes the formation of nitrogenous volatiles from their corresponding precursors. This work provides a major step forward in understanding the biosynthesis of volatile nitrogenous compounds in plants. (Show more)

The relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is a key concept in ecology, but it is rarely investigated in the field. Here we use high-throughput experiments to show that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is sensitive to changes in temperature. We found that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning becomes steeper as temperatures deviate from ambient conditions, indicating that more species are required to maintain ecosystem functioning under thermal stress. This result is driven by two processes linked to the thermal tolerance of taxa. First, more diverse communities have a greater chance of including species with thermal traits that enable them to maintain productivity as temperatures shift from ambient conditions. Second, we found a pronounced increase in the contribution of complementarity to the net biodiversity effect at high and low temperatures, indicating that changes in species interactions played a critical role in mediating the impacts of temperature change on the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. Our results highlight that if biodiversity loss occurs independently of species’ thermal tolerance traits, then the additional impacts of environmental warming will result in sharp declines in ecosystem function.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key hub in the mammalian brain, playing a role in spatial memory and navigation. The organization of its neurons is still debated, and the current study provides a detailed view of the spatial arrangement of MEC neurons in the mouse. We used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of a large number of neurons in the MEC and parasubiculum during free-moving behavior. Our results show that grid cells are spatially segregated from border, head-direction, and object-vector cells, and that grid cells are strongly coupled among themselves. These findings provide a detailed view of the organization of MEC neurons and will help to elucidate the mechanisms underlying spatial learning and memory. (PsycInfo Database Record

The flowering of plants is a complex process, which is controlled by a variety of internal and external factors. In this study, we show that the flowering of the host plant is required for the flowering of the parasite. This study illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness. This study also provides a unique example of the use of the host–parasite system to study the function of the FT gene in flowering regulation. The results of this study may help to elucidate the evolution of flowering in plants and the function of the FT gene in flowering regulation. (Less)

The dopamine systems of the brain powerfully influence movement and motivation. Here, we describe a previously unrecognized system in the brain that is composed of striatonigral fibers originating in striosomes, which form highly unusual bouquet-like arborizations that target bundles of ventrally extending dopamine-containing dendrites and clusters of their parent nigral cell bodies. These clustered cell bodies in turn project to the striatum as part of the classic nigrostriatal pathway. Thus, the striosome–dendron bouquets likely represent subsystems with the nigro–striato–nigral loop that are affected in human disorders including Parkinson’s disease. Given evidence that striosomes receive input from cortical regions related to the control of mood and motivation and that they link functionally to reinforcement and decision-making, the striosome–dendron bouquets could be critical to dopamine-related function in health and disease. This system is likely to be of interest to a broad audience interested in the brain’s dopamine systems and their disorders. (PsycInfo Database Record

We all know when we’re feeling connected to someone, but how do we know when two people are feeling connected to each other? We asked people to talk with each other and rate their felt connection. We found that the speed at which people responded to each other was a robust predictor of how connected they felt. This effect was determined primarily by partner responsivity: People felt more connected to the degree that their partner responded quickly to them rather than by how quickly they responded to their partner. Together, these findings suggest that response times comprise a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.”

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart. SAN cells (SANCs) are responsible for setting the heart rate, and their automaticity is essential for the normal function of the heart. However, the molecular mechanisms that govern SAN automaticity are not fully understood. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is a key regulator of SAN automaticity. We show that STIM1 is expressed in SANCs and is required for the maintenance of their Ca2+ stores. Moreover, we demonstrate that STIM1 regulates the activity of store-operated Ca2+ entry and the Na+/Ca2+ exchanger in SANCs, thereby influencing the automaticity of the SAN. These studies reveal a previously unknown role for STIM1 in the control of SAN automaticity. (Show more)

The beneficial effects of silicon (Si) on plant growth and stress tolerance have been well documented, but the role of Si in mediating insect herbivore resistance has not been explored. Here, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, and that this effect is mediated by an increase in silicon cell deposition and the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway. These results suggest that silicon may be used as a biocontrol agent to enhance insect resistance in rice. (Show more)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is an important enzyme in ether lipid metabolism. We also show that the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase is important for the activation of macrophages and for the expression of inflammatory mediators. Our results suggest that tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase are important regulators of macrophage activation.

Language is a complex cognitive ability that is thought to involve the ability to integrate and store information in working memory. Here we propose a mechanism for memory that is based on changes in the excitability of single neurons. We show that changes in the strength of synaptic connections can support memory on these timescales, but that changes in the intrinsic excitability of neurons are necessary for memory on longer timescales. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a major challenge in the field of plant biology. This is due to the presence of the cell wall, which is absent in mammalian cells and poses the dominant physical barrier to biomolecule delivery in plants. Herein, we report the delivery of siRNAs to plants using DNA nanostructures and show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and attachment location of the siRNA-bearing DNA nanostructures are the key design parameters for the delivery and gene silencing efficiencies. Our work establishes the feasibility of biomolecule delivery to plants with DNA nanostructures and both details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work is expected to be useful for the development of DNA nanostructures as a tool for the delivery of biomolecules to plants. (Show more)

The world’s largest freshwater lakes are vulnerable to coastal eutrophication, which can lead to harmful algal blooms and oxygen depletion. The impacts of nutrient loading on these ecosystems are exacerbated by the presence of large populations around the world’s great lakes. We show that the majority of the nutrient load delivered to the world’s fifth largest lake by volume originates from small tributaries, which are often overlooked in nutrient management efforts. Our findings highlight the importance of small watersheds in driving coastal eutrophication and suggest that nutrient management efforts should focus on these sources to reduce the ecological impacts of nutrient loading on valuable nearshore ecosystems. This work provides a snapshot of the nutrient inputs from all tributaries of a large lake, which can be used to guide future research and monitoring efforts. (Less)

The study of the dynamics of complex systems is a central theme in modern science. In this article, we study the dynamics of a simple model of a chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is difficult to access. We find that the dynamics of the system are biased toward states that are optimized to maximize the access of the environment to the system’s chemical concentrations. This finding has implications for the study of the dynamics of complex systems in general. It also has implications for the study of the dynamics of chemical networks in particular.

The mechanisms by which the immune system can cause seizures are poorly understood. Here we show that the immune system can change the way the brain works, and that this can lead to seizures. We show that the immune system can change the way the brain works, and that this can lead to seizures. The history of abrupt climate change is a key component of our understanding of the Earth system and its response to external forcing. However, the history of abrupt climate change is poorly understood, in part because of the difficulty in identifying and quantifying abrupt events in the geologic record. Here, we present a case study of an abrupt climate change event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that this event can be linked to a global warming and an injection of organic matter–derived carbon into the ocean. Our results provide insights into the history of abrupt climate change and the Earth system response to external forcing. (Less)

The palm oil industry is a major driver of tropical deforestation, and the Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) is the leading certification scheme. Despite the importance of the palm oil industry, the impact of RSPO certification on deforestation has not been evaluated. We show that RSPO certification is associated with a 33% reduction in deforestation from 2001 to 2015. However, certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation. Our results suggest that the RSPO is not currently achieving its stated goal of reducing deforestation. (Less)

The exocyst complex is a multisubunit complex that is involved in the last steps of exocytosis, which is essential to organisms across kingdoms. The exocyst complex is composed of 11 subunits, of which 7 are essential for the function of the complex. The function of the exocyst complex is conserved across kingdoms, and its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and offers a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

The evolution of sex determination is a major topic of study in developmental biology. In this study, we investigate the evolution of secondary sexual characteristics in a species with polygenic sex determination, where the sex of an individual is determined by the combination of alleles at multiple loci. We find that the interplay of multiple sex determination alleles in this species produces a modular evolution of secondary sexual characteristics, including the shape of the head and mouth, the shape of the genital organs, and the behavior of the fish. This modular evolution of secondary sexual characteristics provides context for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of the maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations. (Less)

The retina is a unique organ that is challenged by the presence of reactive oxygen species and reactive carbonyl species that are generated by photooxidation of the retinal pigment epithelium. The retina is also challenged by the presence of iron, which is a cofactor for many of these reactions. We show that the presence of iron in the retina promotes the photooxidation and degradation of the retinal pigment epithelium’s main photoreceptor cell pigment, A2E. These findings have implications for the pathogenesis of age-related macular degeneration, a leading cause of blindness in the United States. They also have implications for the use of iron chelators in the treatment of age-related macular degeneration. (PsycINFO Database Record

Predators are the main drivers of biodiversity and ecosystem functioning, and thus, their evolution is of great interest to ecology and evolution. However, the evolution of predators is often considered a dead end, as it is difficult to evolve new morphological and functional traits in the whole organism. Here we show that the evolution of predators can be modular, and that specialization can be linked to the evolution of separate structures dedicated to prey capture. Our findings contribute to understanding how specialization and morphological evolution have shaped present-day food webs. They also help build a broader perspective on predatory niche diversification via morphological innovation and evolution.

The evolution of the human hand is a key area of research in human evolution. The study of the hand is complicated by the fact that the hand is a complex and mobile structure, and the fossil record is sparse in the hominin fossil record between 800,000 and 1.8 My old. We report the discovery of a hominin hand fossil from the Middle Pleistocene to recent period, which provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key derived characteristic of modern human and Neandertal hand morphology. This finding suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo and probably in Homo erectus sensu lato. This is an important finding for understanding the evolution of the human hand. (Less)

The one-carbon unit is essential for cell growth, and is provided by the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT). SHMT is up-regulated in cancer, and the enzyme is a promising target for cancer therapy. Here we describe the discovery of small-molecule dual inhibitors of SHMT1 and SHMT2, and show that these compounds are effective in vitro and in vivo. We also show that one-carbon donor formate is a potent rescue of SHMT inhibition in cancer cells, but paradoxically increases the inhibitor’s cytotoxicity in a subset of cancer cell lines. These findings have implications for the design of cancer therapeutics. (Less)

The role of natural landscapes in improving people’s diets is not well understood. This study shows that deforestation can reduce people’s consumption of fruits and vegetables and thus their vitamin A intake. The results also show that forest fragmentation can increase people’s consumption of fruits and vegetables and thus their vitamin A intake. The findings have important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals. The study also highlights the importance of using a causal modeling approach to understand the effects of deforestation on people’s diets. The use of farm machinery has greatly increased the productivity of modern agriculture, but it has also led to the compaction of soil, which is a major threat to the sustainability of agricultural systems. We show that the increase in the weight of farm machinery has led to the propagation of compaction into deeper soil layers, which now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We developed a global map for delineating subsoil compaction susceptibility based on estimates of mechanization level, mean tractor size, soil texture, and climatic conditions. The alarming trend of chronic subsoil compaction risk over 20% of arable land, with potential loss of productivity, calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. As the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, a paradox emerges of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction. We hypothesize that unconstrained roaming of sauropods would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants.
